Award.AwardTitle: CO Hydrogenation to Long-chain Terminal Alcohols and Aldehydes: A Combined Approach by Transient Kinetics and Theoretical Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract Title: CO Hydrogenation to Long-chain Terminal Alcohols and Aldehydes: A Combined Approach by Transient Kinetics and Theoretical Modeling


Homogeneous catalysts are widely used in industrial chemical processes for the production of long chain alcohols and aldehydes, which can then be used as feedstock for other chemical processes. This production process has several disadvantages as it involves several process steps and because the expensive precious noble metals in the catalysts have to be carefully recovered. An alternative way to produce long chain alcohols is by using a heterogeneous catalyst which adds hydrogen to carbon monoxide, employing catalysts made of earth abundant metals such as cobalt or iron. Such technology plays a major role in the petrochemical industry where the interest is in the production of long-chain hydrocarbons. There has been less application when it comes to the production of long chain oxygenated hydrocarbons. While it is known that different metals have different catalytic properties, the rational design of catalysts which can produce mostly useful products with minimum production of side-products remains a major challenge in industrial laboratories. However, recent research findings have shown that the heterogeneous catalysis route can in fact be a 'one-step, one-pot' process with no risk of valuable noble metal loss. This award, made to Professors Norbert Kruse and Jean-Sabin McEwen in the Center for Catalysis at Washington State University, aims at providing the essential scientific basis for the design of catalysts with superior catalytic activity and performance for the production of long-chain oxygenates from carbon monoxide. The implications of such a process are especially important in terms of closing the cost gap between chemical products that are traditionally based on fossil fuels and those which could be based on carbon monoxide instead. The PIs will also establish a partnership with the Phillips 66 Company Ferndale, WA refinery, where undergraduate and graduate students will be given the opportunity to meet with the company's representatives so as to discuss their project results, visit the company's production site and, consequently, understand industrial-scale and commercial implications of their work.



The targeted design of catalysts for long-chain oxygenate production via the Fischer Tropsch technology becomes possible by using oxalate co-precipitation of metal precursors as developed in the laboratories Washington State. This preparation technique involves all metal components in a single step, so no classical support material is needed. Relative amounts of metal precursors can be straightforwardly varied so as to tune the composition for selective oxygenates production via CO hydrogenation. Catalysts will be comprised of Co and Cu metal functions, of the Co core-Cu shell structures. Microkinetic data as provided in combined chemical transient kinetics and density functional theory calculations will include a 'surface atom counting' of carbon, oxygen and hydrogen at any instant until steady state conditions are reached. Energy profiles for bimetallic CoCu particles on various oxide surfaces at high surface coverages will be performed and correlated to the transient kinetic data so as to optimize the high pressure CO hydrogenation process to long-chain oxygenates. It is anticipated that these research efforts will lead to a new generation of catalysts for selective C8-14 oxygenates production.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Homogeneous catalysts are widely used in industrial chemical processes for the production of long chain alcohols and aldehydes, products which can then be used as feedstock for other chemical processes. This production process, also known as hydroformylation, has disadvantages as it involves several process steps and because the expensive precious noble metals in the catalysts have to be carefully recovered. An alternative way to produce long chain alcohols is by using a heterogeneous catalyst, made of earth abundant metals such as cobalt or iron on a support material, and to use hydrogen and carbon monoxide in a polymerization-type process, where the carbon atoms bond in sequence to produce long chains, to directly synthesize these products. Such technology plays a major role in the petrochemical industry where the interest is in the production of long-chain hydrocarbons serving as diesel fuel. There has been less application when it comes to the production of long chain oxygen-containing hydrocarbons. While it is known that different metals have different catalytic properties, the rational design of catalysts that can produce useful products with minimum production of unwanted side-products remains a major challenge in industrial laboratories. However, recent research findings have shown that the heterogeneous catalysis route can in fact be a 'one-step, one-pot' process with no risk of valuable noble metal loss. In this project, Professors Norbert Kruse and Jean-Sabin McEwen in the Center for Catalysis at Washington State University, aimed at providing the essential scientific basis for the design of catalysts with superior catalytic activity and performance for the production of long-chain oxygen-containing hydrocarbons from carbon monoxide and hydrogen. The implications of such a process are especially important in terms of closing the cost gap between chemical products that are traditionally based on fossil fuels and those that could be based on syngas instead. The project also established a partnership with the Phillips 66 Company Ferndale, WA refinery, where undergraduate and graduate students were given the opportunity to meet with the company's representatives, visit the company's production site and, consequently, understand industrial-scale and commercial implications of their work. Finally, the project gave the McEwen group the opportunity to collaborate with Dr. Saeys at Ghent University, Dr. Alexandrova at the University of California Los Angeles and Dr. Stampfl at the University of Sydney.

The findings of this study resulted in four important experimental outcomes regarding the performance of ternary catalysts based on binary cobalt-copper and cobalt-manganese that are deposited on titania or niobia, which act as a support. First, the project elaborated on the role of these supports as well as the effect of changing the hydrogen to carbon monoxide ratio on the reaction mechanism. Second, when moving to high pressures, we found that products containing no oxygen are largely replaced by those containing it.  Competing mechanisms were proposed as a function of reaction time and varying experimental conditions to explain these findings. Third, the behavior of reactive and unreactive metal oxide supports was investigated under different reaction conditions. Fourth, the importance of a cobalt (pure metal) to cobalt carbide (metal with carbon imbedded) phase transformation and its dependence on the hydrogen to carbon monoxide ratio at regular and higher-pressure conditions was clearly demonstrated. The cobalt carbide phase turned out to be beneficial for the production of oxygen-containing products.

There are four important outcomes on the theory side. First, the carbon monoxide bond was shown to be weakened when brought near the metal-oxide interface. Second, the interactions between carbon monoxide molecules adsorbed on a cobalt-based catalyst were quantified using quantum chemical calculations. Third, the calculations further suggested how the presence of copper will influence the interaction of carbon monoxide with either a flat or a stepped cobalt surface leading to changes in the shape of the catalyst which is a phenomenon that has been experimentally observed. Fourth, a rigorous but simplified mathematical model of carbon monoxide adsorption on cobalt surfaces was constructed to facilitate larger scale simulations in more complex binary and ternary systems that cannot be modeled using quantum mechanics like those investigated by the Kruse group.

Through several conference presentations, this project had a significant number of broader impacts in the scientific community. Further, our work was performed in close collaboration with experiment. Such an approach is needed if one wants to truly understand how and why a catalyst works, which can then be used in other chemical reaction studies. This project has engaged two graduate students and one postdoctoral researcher. Outreach activities for K-12 students were developed so as to educate them about how catalysis impacts their daily lives, and specifically how emission catalysis is important to protect the environment and human health. During this project period, this activity was delivered to a high school classroom (~20 students) on a Native American reserve.

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2020
Modified by: Jean-Sabin Mcewen
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Homogeneous catalysts are widely used in industrial chemical processes for the production of long chain alcohols and aldehydes, products which can then be used as feedstock for other chemical processes. This production process, also known as hydroformylation, has disadvantages as it involves several process steps and because the expensive precious noble metals in the catalysts have to be carefully recovered. An alternative way to produce long chain alcohols is by using a heterogeneous catalyst, made of earth abundant metals such as cobalt or iron on a support material, and to use hydrogen and carbon monoxide in a polymerization-type process, where the carbon atoms bond in sequence to produce long chains, to directly synthesize these products. Such technology plays a major role in the petrochemical industry where the interest is in the production of long-chain hydrocarbons serving as diesel fuel. There has been less application when it comes to the production of long chain oxygen-containing hydrocarbons. While it is known that different metals have different catalytic properties, the rational design of catalysts that can produce useful products with minimum production of unwanted side-products remains a major challenge in industrial laboratories. However, recent research findings have shown that the heterogeneous catalysis route can in fact be a 'one-step, one-pot' process with no risk of valuable noble metal loss. In this project, Professors Norbert Kruse and Jean-Sabin McEwen in the Center for Catalysis at Washington State University, aimed at providing the essential scientific basis for the design of catalysts with superior catalytic activity and performance for the production of long-chain oxygen-containing hydrocarbons from carbon monoxide and hydrogen. The implications of such a process are especially important in terms of closing the cost gap between chemical products that are traditionally based on fossil fuels and those that could be based on syngas instead. The project also established a partnership with the Phillips 66 Company Ferndale, WA refinery, where undergraduate and graduate students were given the opportunity to meet with the company's representatives, visit the company's production site and, consequently, understand industrial-scale and commercial implications of their work. Finally, the project gave the McEwen group the opportunity to collaborate with Dr. Saeys at Ghent University, Dr. Alexandrova at the University of California Los Angeles and Dr. Stampfl at the University of Sydney. The findings of this study resulted in four important experimental outcomes regarding the performance of ternary catalysts based on binary cobalt-copper and cobalt-manganese that are deposited on titania or niobia, which act as a support. First, the project elaborated on the role of these supports as well as the effect of changing the hydrogen to carbon monoxide ratio on the reaction mechanism. Second, when moving to high pressures, we found that products containing no oxygen are largely replaced by those containing it. Competing mechanisms were proposed as a function of reaction time and varying experimental conditions to explain these findings. Third, the behavior of reactive and unreactive metal oxide supports was investigated under different reaction conditions. Fourth, the importance of a cobalt (pure metal) to cobalt carbide (metal with carbon imbedded) phase transformation and its dependence on the hydrogen to carbon monoxide ratio at regular and higher-pressure conditions was clearly demonstrated. The cobalt carbide phase turned out to be beneficial for the production of oxygen-containing products. There are four important outcomes on the theory side. First, the carbon monoxide bond was shown to be weakened when brought near the metal-oxide interface. Second, the interactions between carbon monoxide molecules adsorbed on a cobalt-based catalyst were quantified using quantum chemical calculations. Third, the calculations further suggested how the presence of copper will influence the interaction of carbon monoxide with either a flat or a stepped cobalt surface leading to changes in the shape of the catalyst which is a phenomenon that has been experimentally observed. Fourth, a rigorous but simplified mathematical model of carbon monoxide adsorption on cobalt surfaces was constructed to facilitate larger scale simulations in more complex binary and ternary systems that cannot be modeled using quantum mechanics like those investigated by the Kruse group. Through several conference presentations, this project had a significant number of broader impacts in the scientific community. Further, our work was performed in close collaboration with experiment. Such an approach is needed if one wants to truly understand how and why a catalyst works, which can then be used in other chemical reaction studies. This project has engaged two graduate students and one postdoctoral researcher. Outreach activities for K-12 students were developed so as to educate them about how catalysis impacts their daily lives, and specifically how emission catalysis is important to protect the environment and human health. During this project period, this activity was delivered to a high school classroom (~20 students) on a Native American reserve. Last Modified: 01/30/2020 Submitted by: Jean-Sabin Mcewen
